34.verse: And when he had brought them up into his house, he set food before them; and he rejoiced, having placed his faith in God along with his entire household.

35.verse: But when it was day, the magistrates sent their constables, saying, “Release those men.”

36.verse: And the jailer reported these words to Paul, saying, “The magistrates have sent orders to release you. So depart now and go in peace.”

37.verse: But Paul said to them, “They have beaten us publicly, uncondemned, men who are Roman citizens, and have thrown us into prison; and now would they send us away in secret? No indeed! They themselves must come and escort us out.”

38.verse: The constables reported these words to the magistrates. And they were afraid when they heard that they were Roman citizens.

39.verse: So they came and spoke to them in a friendly manner; and having taken them out, they asked them to leave the city.

40.verse: So when they had left the prison, they went to Lydia’s house; and when they saw the brothers, they encouraged them and departed.

1.verse: Having passed through Amphipolis and Apollonia, Paul and Silas came to Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.

2.verse: And according to Paul’s custom, he went to them and for three Sabbath days he reasoned with them from the Scriptures,

3.verse: explaining and demonstrating that it was necessary for the Messiah to suffer and to rise from the dead, and that, “This one is the Messiah, this Jesus whom I am proclaiming to you.”

4.verse: And some of them were persuaded and cast their lot with Paul and Silas, both a great number of devout Greeks and not a few of the leading women.

5.verse: But the Jews, moved by envy, recruited certain wicked men of the marketplace and, forming a mob, they set the city in an uproar. They attacked the house of Jason, trying to bring them out to the people.

6.verse: But when they could not find them, they dragged Jason and some fellow believers before the city authorities, shouting, “These men who have turned the world upside down have come here too,

7.verse: and Jason has received them as guests; and all these men are acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus.”

8.verse: And they stirred up the people and the city authorities who heard these things.

9.verse: And when they had taken bail from Jason and the others, they let them go.

10.verse: And the brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas off by night to Berea. When they got there, they went to the synagogue of the Jews.

11.verse: These Jews were more open-minded than those in Thessalonica, for they received the message with all eagerness, examining the scriptures every day to see if these things were so.

12.verse: So many of them believed, with not a few prominent Greek women and men.

13.verse: But when the Jews from Thessalonica learned that also in Berea the word of God was proclaimed by Paul, they came there too, inciting and stirring up the crowds.

14.verse: Then immediately the brothers sent Paul away, to go as far as to the sea, but both Silas and Timothy remained there.

15.verse: Those who conducted Paul brought him as far as Athens, and receiving an order for Silas and Timothy to come to him as soon as possible, they left.

16.verse: Now while Paul was waiting for them at Athens, his spirit was stirred up within him on seeing the city full of idols.

17.verse: So he reasoned in the synagogue with the Jews and the worshippers, and in the marketplace every day with those who happened to be there.

18.verse: Also some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers were conversing with him, and some were asking, “What does this babbler want to say?” Others said, “He seems to be a proclaimer of strange gods,” for he was announcing the good news about Jesus and the resurrection.

19.verse: And they took hold of him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, “May we know what is this new teaching being presented by you?

20.verse: For you bring some strange things to our ears, so we want to know what these things mean.”

21.verse: (Now all the Athenians and the foreigners living there used to spend their time in nothing else than to tell or to hear something new.)

22.verse: So Paul, standing in the midst of the Areopagus, said: “Men of Athens, I perceive that in every way you are a very devout people.

23.verse: For as I went around and observed your objects of worship, I found also an altar on which was inscribed, ‘To an unknown god.’ So what you worship without knowing, this I proclaim to you.

24.verse: The God who made the world and everything in it, being Lord of heaven and earth, does not live in shrines made by human hands,

25.verse: nor is he served by human hands, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives to all life and breath and everything.

26.verse: And he made from one man every race of men to live on all the face of the earth, having determined allotted epochs and the fixed boundaries of the places where they would live,

27.verse: that they should seek God, if perhaps that they might grope for him and find him, though indeed he is not far from each one of us.

28.verse: ‘For in him we live and move about and exist,’ as even some of your own poets have said, ‘For we too are his offspring.’

29.verse: So since we are the offspring of God, we ought not to think that the divine being is like an image carved in gold or silver or stone by human skill and imagination.

30.verse: So then, God overlooked the times of ignorance, but now he orders men to repent, all of them in all places,

31.verse: because he has appointed a day on which he will judge the world in righteousness by the man whom he has appointed, having provided proof to all by raising him from the dead.”

32.verse: Now when they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some mocked, but others said, “We will hear you again about this.”

33.verse: So Paul departed from their midst.

34.verse: But some men joined him and believed; among whom also were Dionysius the Areopagite and a woman named Damaris and others with them.

1.verse: After this Paul departed from Athens and went to Corinth.

2.verse: And finding a certain Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, recently come from Italy with his wife Priscilla because Claudius had commanded all the Jews to depart from Rome, he approached them,

3.verse: and because he was of the same trade he stayed with them and worked, for they were tentmakers by trade.

4.verse: And he reasoned in the synagogue every Sabbath and tried to persuade Jews and Greeks.

5.verse: When Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul was wholly absorbed with preaching the word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus was the Messiah.

6.verse: But when they opposed and reviled him, he shook out his garments and said to them, “Your blood be on your own head! I am guiltless. From now on I will go to the Gentiles.”

7.verse: And he left there and went to the house of one named Titius Justus, a worshiper of God, whose house was next door to the synagogue.

8.verse: Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord, together with his entire household; and many of the Corinthians upon hearing about it, believed and were baptized.

9.verse: And the Lord said to Paul during the night in a vision, “Do not be afraid, but go on speaking and do not be silent,

10.verse: because I am with you and no one will lay a hand on you to do you harm, for I have many people in this city.”

11.verse: So he stayed there a year and six months, teaching among them the word of God.

12.verse: But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews rose up with one accord against Paul and brought him before the tribunal,

13.verse: saying, “This man is persuading men to worship God in a way contrary to the law.”

14.verse: But when Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, “If it were a matter of wrongdoing or a serious piece of villainy, O Jews, it would be reasonable for me to put up with you.

15.verse: But if the questions are about a word and names and your own law, see to it yourselves. I do not wish to be a judge of these matters.”

16.verse: And he drove them from the tribunal.

17.verse: And they all took hold of Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and began to beat him in front of the tribunal. But none of these things were of concern to Gallio.

18.verse: Paul, after remaining there for a number of days, said farewell to the brothers and sailed away to Syria, and with him were Priscilla and Aquila. At Cenchreae he had his head shaved, for he had taken a vow.

19.verse: And they went to Ephesus, and he left them there but he himself went into the synagogue and reasoned with the Jews.

20.verse: When they asked him to stay a longer time, he would not consent

21.verse: but bade farewell, saying, “I will come back to you again, God willing.” Then he set sail from Ephesus,

22.verse: and when he touched land at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the church and then went down to Antioch.

23.verse: After spending some time there, he departed and made his way from place to place through the Galatian country and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.

24.verse: Now a Jew named Apollos, an Alexandrian by race, arrived in Ephesus. He was an eloquent man, well-versed in the Scriptures.

25.verse: He had been instructed in the way of the Lord; and being fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught accurately the facts about Jesus, though he knew only the baptism of John.

26.verse: He began to speak boldly in the synagogue, but when they heard him, Priscilla and Aquila took him and explained more accurately to him the way of God.

27.verse: And when he wanted to continue on into Achaia, the brothers encouraged him and wrote to the disciples to welcome him. When he arrived there, he greatly helped those who had come to believe through grace,

28.verse: for he powerfully refuted the Jews in public, demonstrating by the Scriptures that Jesus was the Messiah.

1.verse: And it happened that while Apollos was at Corinth, Paul went through the inland regions and came to Ephesus. There he found some disciples

2.verse: and said to them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?” They said to him, “Why, we have not even heard if there is a Holy Spirit.”

3.verse: So Paul asked, “Into what then were you baptized?” And they replied, “Into the baptism of John.”

4.verse: Paul said, “John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people to believe in the one coming after him, that is, in Jesus.”

5.verse: Upon hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.

6.verse: And when Paul laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they spoke in tongues and prophesied.

7.verse: And the men were in all about twelve.

8.verse: And he went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for three months, reasoning and persuading them concerning the things of the kingdom of God.

9.verse: But when some became stubborn and refused to believe, speaking evil of the Way before the congregation, he withdrew from them, taking the disciples with him, and continued daily to discourse in the lecture hall of Tyrannus.

10.verse: This went on for two years, so that all the residents of Asia heard the word of the Lord, both Jews and Greeks.

11.verse: They were no ordinary miracles that God was doing by the hands of Paul,

12.verse: so that handkerchiefs and aprons were carried off from his body for the sick, and diseases were driven away by them and evil spirits came out.

13.verse: But some also of the itinerant Jews, exorcists, tried to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those having evil spirits, saying, “I adjure you by that Jesus whom Paul proclaims.”

14.verse: There were seven sons of a man named Sceva, a Jewish high priest, who were doing this.

15.verse: But the evil spirit answering said to them, “Jesus I know, and Paul I recognize, but who are you?”

16.verse: And the man in whom was the evil spirit leaped on them, took control and overpowered all seven of them, so that they fled, naked and wounded, out of that house.

17.verse: And this became known to all the Jews and Greeks who lived in Ephesus. And fear fell upon them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was exalted.

18.verse: Also many of those who had become believers kept coming, confessing and divulging their practices.

19.verse: And a number of those who had practiced magic arts collected their books and burned them up in the sight of all. And they calculated the value of them and found it to be fifty thousand pieces of silver.

20.verse: So the word of the Lord continued to spread and grow in power.

21.verse: Now after all these things had taken place, Paul resolved in spirit to pass through Macedonia and Achaia and go on to Jerusalem, saying, “After I have been there, I must also see Rome.”

22.verse: So after sending to Macedonia two of those who were helping him, Timothy and Erastus, he himself stayed for a time in Asia.

23.verse: About that time there broke out no little disturbance concerning the Way.

24.verse: For a man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Artemis, brought no little business to the craftsmen.

25.verse: He called them together with workmen in similar trades, and said, “Men, you know that from this trade prosperity comes to us.

26.verse: And you see and hear that not only in Ephesus but in almost all of Asia this Paul has persuaded and turned away a considerable number of people, saying that gods made by hand are not gods at all.

27.verse: There is danger not only that this trade of ours will fall into disrepute, but also that the temple of the great goddess Artemis is in danger of being regarded as worthless and her magnificence in danger of being destroyed, she whom all Asia and the world worship.”

28.verse: When they heard this, they were filled with anger and began to cry out, saying, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

29.verse: So the city was filled with the confusion, and they rushed with a single purpose into the theater, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians, traveling-companions of Paul.

30.verse: But when Paul wanted to go in among the people, the disciples would not let him.

31.verse: And also some of the Asiarchs, being friendly to him, sent to him and urged him not to commit himself to the theater.

32.verse: So then some were shouting one thing, some another, for the assembly was in confusion, and most of them did not know why they had assembled.

33.verse: And some of the crowd prompted Alexander, the Jews pushing him forward. And Alexander motioned with his hand and wanted to make a defense to the crowd.

34.verse: But when they recognized that he was a Jew, a single cry went up from them all as they cried out for about two hours, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

35.verse: And when the city clerk had quieted the crowd, he said, “Men of Ephesus, what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the temple keeper of the great Artemis and of her image that fell from heaven?

36.verse: So, since these things are indisputable, you must be quiet and do nothing rash.

37.verse: For you have brought these men, who are neither temple robbers nor blasphemers against our goddess.

38.verse: If then Demetrius and the craftsmen with him have a complaint against anyone, the courts are open, and there are proconsuls. Let them bring charges against one another there.

39.verse: But if you want anything in addition, it shall be settled in the legal assembly.

40.verse: For indeed we are in danger of being charged in connection with this day’s riot, there being no cause for it; and we will not be able to give an explanation for this commotion.” And having said this, he dismissed the assembly.

41.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

1.verse: After the uproar ceased, Paul sent for the disciples, and after encouraging them and saying farewell, he left for Macedonia.

2.verse: When he had gone through those parts and encouraged them with many words, he came to Greece.

3.verse: He spent three months there, and when a plot was hatched against him by the Jews as he was about to set sail for Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.

4.verse: Sopater, the son of Pyrrhus from Berea, went with him, as did Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonians, Gaius a resident of Derbe, Timothy, and the Asians, Tychicus and Trophimus.

5.verse: These men had gone on ahead and were waiting for us in Troas.

6.verse: We sailed away after the days of Unleavened Bread from Philippi and joined the others in Troas five days later, where we stayed for seven days.

7.verse: On the first day of the week, when we had gathered to break bread, Paul addressed them, and since he intended to leave the next day, he continued his message until midnight.

8.verse: There were a number of lamps in the upper room where we had gathered.

9.verse: And a young man, named Eutychus, sitting on the window ledge, was sinking into a deep sleep as Paul continued to speak on and on. Overcome by sleep, he fell from the third floor and was picked up for dead.

10.verse: But Paul went down and threw himself on him, and putting his arms around him, said, “Do not be alarmed, for his life is in him.”

11.verse: Then Paul went back upstairs, and after he had broken bread and eaten, he spoke with them a considerable time, until dawn, and so he departed.

12.verse: And they took the boy home alive and were encouraged not a little.

13.verse: We, then, went on to the ship and set sail for Assos, where we planned to take Paul on board; for he had made this arrangement, intending himself to travel by land.

14.verse: When he met us at Assos, we took him on board and continued on to Mitylene.

15.verse: And from there we sailed away on the following day and arrived off the shore of Chios, the next day we touched at Samos, and the day after that we went to Miletus.

16.verse: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he might not have to spend time in Asia, for he was hastening, if it were possible for him, to be in Jerusalem for the day of Pentecost.

17.verse: From Miletus he sent to Ephesus, asking the elders of the church to come to him.

18.verse: And when they came to him, he said to them: “You yourselves know how I lived among you the whole time from the first day on which I set foot in Asia,

19.verse: serving the Lord with all humility and with tears, enduring the trials that fell on me by the plots of the Jews;

20.verse: how I did not hold back from proclaiming to you anything that would be helpful, and from teaching you publicly from house to house,

21.verse: testifying both to Jews and to Greeks about repentance toward God and about faith in our Lord Jesus.

22.verse: And now, compelled by the Spirit, I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,

23.verse: except that the Holy Spirit testifies to me, saying that in every city imprisonment and persecutions are waiting for me.

24.verse: But I make my life of no account as of any value to me, that I may finish my task and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the good news of the grace of God.

25.verse: “And now I know that none of you will see my face again, you among whom I went about proclaiming the kingdom.

26.verse: Therefore I testify to you this day that I am innocent of the blood of you all,

27.verse: for I did not shrink from announcing to you the whole purpose of God.

28.verse: Watch out for yourselves and for all the flock in which the Holy Spirit has placed you overseers, to shepherd the church of God, which he purchased with the blood of his own Son.

29.verse: I know that there will come to you after my departure savage wolves, not sparing the flock.

30.verse: Even from among your own group will men arise, speaking distortions of the truth, to draw the disciples away after them.

31.verse: Therefore be alert, remembering that for three years, night or day, I did not cease warning each one of you with tears.

32.verse: And now I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up and to give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.

33.verse: I have not coveted anyone’s silver or gold or clothing.

34.verse: You yourselves know that these hands of mine provided for my own needs as well as the needs of those with me.

35.verse: In all this I have shown you that by working in this way you must help the weak, remembering the words of the Lord Jesus, how he himself said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”

36.verse: And when he had said these things, he knelt down with them all and prayed.

37.verse: And there was much weeping on the part of all, and they fell on the neck of Paul and kissed him lovingly,

38.verse: being saddened most of all because of the word he had spoken, that no longer were they going to see his face. And they escorted him to the ship.

1.verse: And when we had parted from them, we put out to sea and sailed on a straight course to Cos, then on the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.

2.verse: And finding a ship bound for Phoenicia, we went aboard and set sail.

3.verse: We came in sight of Cyprus, and leaving it behind on our port side, we sailed on to Syria and landed at Tyre, for there the ship was to unload its cargo.

4.verse: After locating the disciples, we stayed there seven days; and they kept telling Paul through the Spirit not to set foot in Jerusalem.

5.verse: When our days there were ended, we departed and went on our journey, and they all, with wives and children, accompanied us until we were outside the city. Then kneeling down on the beach, we prayed

6.verse: and said farewell to one another. Then we went on board the ship, and they returned to their own homes.

7.verse: And having completed the voyage from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais, and we greeted the brothers and stayed one day with them.

8.verse: On the next day we departed and went to Caesarea. There we went into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.

9.verse: (He had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.)

10.verse: While we were staying for many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.

11.verse: He came to us and, taking Paul’s belt, he tied his own hands and feet with it and said, “The Holy Spirit says this: ‘This is how the Jews will tie up in Jerusalem the man whose belt this is, and will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.’”

12.verse: When we heard this, both we and the local people urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.

13.verse: Then Paul answered, “What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be tied up but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”

14.verse: And since he would not be persuaded, we fell silent, saying, “Let the will of the Lord be done.”

15.verse: After these days we got ready and started up to Jerusalem.

16.verse: And some of the disciples from Caesarea came with us, bringing Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should lodge.

17.verse: When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brothers welcomed us gladly.

18.verse: On the following day Paul went with us to James, and all the elders were present.

19.verse: After he greeted them, he began to relate one by one what God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.

20.verse: And when they heard it, they began to praise God. And they said to him, “You see, brother, how many thousands of believers there are among the Jews, and they are all zealous for the law.

21.verse: But they were told about you that you are teaching all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children and not to walk according to our customs.

22.verse: What then is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.

23.verse: Therefore, do what we tell you. There are with us four men who have taken upon themselves a vow.

24.verse: Take these men and purify yourself along with them and pay their expenses that they may shave their heads, and everyone will know that there is nothing in what they have been told about you, but that you yourself walk keeping the law.

25.verse: But as for the Gentiles who have believed, we sent a letter with our judgment that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, and from blood, and from what has been strangled, and from sexual immorality.”

26.verse: Then Paul took the men and on the next day he purified himself with them and went into the temple, giving notice of the completion of the days of the purification, at which time the sacrifice would be offered on behalf of each one of them.

27.verse: When the seven days were about to be completed, the Jews from Asia, upon seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,

28.verse: crying out, “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who is teaching everyone everywhere against our people, our law, and this place. And besides, he even brought Greeks into the temple and has made this holy place unclean.”

29.verse: For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in the city with him, and they assumed that Paul had taken him into the temple.

30.verse: Then all the city was stirred up, and a mob of people quickly formed. They seized Paul and dragged him outside the temple, and immediately the gates were shut.

31.verse: And while they were trying to kill him, a report was sent up to the commanding officer of the detachment that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.

32.verse: At once he took along some soldiers and centurions and ran down to them; and when they saw the commanding officer and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.

33.verse: Then the commanding officer came up and arrested him and ordered him to be tied up with two chains. Then he asked who he might be and what he had done.

34.verse: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing, some another, and since he was unable to find out the truth because of the uproar, he ordered him to be brought into the barracks.

35.verse: When he got to the stairs, Paul had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the mob,

36.verse: for the crowd of people kept following and shouting, “Away with him!”

37.verse: As he was about to be brought into the barracks, Paul said to the commanding officer, “Is it allowed for me to say something to you?” He replied, “Do you know Greek?

38.verse: Then you are not the Egyptian who prior to these days stirred up a revolt and led into the desert the four thousand men of the Assassins?”

39.verse: But Paul replied, “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no obscure city. I beg you, allow me to speak to the people.”

40.verse: And when he had given him permission, Paul stood on the steps and motioned with his hand to the people. And when there was a great hush, he addressed them in the Hebrew language, saying:

1.verse: “My brothers and fathers, listen now to me as I make my defense to you.”

2.verse: And when they heard that he was addressing them in the Hebrew language, they became even more quiet. And he said:

3.verse: “I am a Jewish man, born in Tarsus of Cilicia, but brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, educated according to the strictness of the ancestral law, being zealous for God just as you all are today.

4.verse: I persecuted the followers of this Way even to their death, putting in chains both men and women and delivering them to prison,

5.verse: as also the high priest and the whole council of elders can bear me witness. From them I received letters to the brothers, and I went toward Damascus to take those also who were there and bring them in bonds to Jerusalem to be punished.

6.verse: As I journeyed and came near to Damascus, about noon suddenly out of heaven flashed a brilliant light all around me.

7.verse: I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’

8.verse: And I answered, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And he said to me, ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.’

9.verse: Now those who were with me saw the light but did not understand the voice of the one who was speaking to me.

10.verse: And I said, ‘What shall I do, Lord?’ And the Lord said to me, ‘Get up and go on into Damascus, and there it will be told you about all that has been assigned to you to do.’

11.verse: Since I could not see due to the brilliance of that light, being led by the hand by those who were with me, I went to Damascus.

12.verse: “Then a certain Ananias, a devout man according to the law, well spoken of by all the Jews who lived there,

13.verse: came to me, and standing there said to me, ‘Brother Saul, recover your sight.’ And at that very hour I recovered my sight and saw him.

14.verse: And he said, ‘The God of our fathers has chosen you to know his will, to see the Righteous One and to hear a voice from his mouth.

15.verse: For you will be a witness for him to everyone of what you have seen and heard.

16.verse: And now why are you waiting? Rise and be baptized and wash away your sins, calling on his name.’

17.verse: When I had returned to Jerusalem and I was praying in the temple, I fell into a trance

18.verse: and I saw him saying to me, ‘Make haste and get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’

19.verse: And I said, ‘Lord, they themselves know that I used to go from one synagogue to another imprisoning and flogging those who believed in you.

20.verse: And when the blood of Stephen, your witness, was being shed, I myself was standing by approving and guarding the cloaks of those who were killing him.’

21.verse: And he said to me, ‘Go, for I will send you far away to the Gentiles.’”

22.verse: They listened to him until this word, but then they raised their voices saying, “Away with such a fellow from the earth, for it is not right for him to live!”

23.verse: While they were crying out and throwing off their cloaks and flinging dust in the air,

24.verse: the commanding officer ordered Paul to be brought back into the barracks, saying that he should be examined with whips so that he might know the reason why they were shouting at him that way.

25.verse: But when they had stretched him out for the lash, Paul said to the centurion standing by, “Is it lawful for you to flog a man who is a Roman citizen and uncondemned?”

26.verse: When the centurion heard this, he went and reported to the commanding officer, saying, “What are you about to do? For this man is a Roman citizen.”

27.verse: The commanding officer came to him and said, “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?” He replied, “Yes.”

28.verse: The commanding officer answered, “I obtained this citizenship with a large sum of money.” Paul answered, “But I was even born one.”

29.verse: Immediately those who were about to examine him drew back from him; and the commanding officer was afraid, realizing that Paul was a Roman citizen and that he had bound him.

30.verse: But on the next day, wanting to know for sure what was the accusation being made against him by the Jews, he released him and ordered the chief priests and all the council to meet, and he brought Paul down and set him before them.

1.verse: Looking intently at the council, Paul said, “My brothers, I have lived in all good conscience before God up to this day.”

2.verse: At that the high priest Ananias ordered those standing near him to strike him on the mouth.

3.verse: Then Paul said to him, “God is about to strike you, you whitewashed wall! Do you indeed sit judging me according to the law yet contrary to the law order me to be struck?”

4.verse: Those standing near him said, “Dare you insult God’s high priest?”

5.verse: And Paul said, “I did not realize, brothers, that he was high priest; for it is written, ‘You shall not speak evil about the ruler of your people.’”

6.verse: Now when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, “My brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. It is regarding my hope of a resurrection for the dead that I am on trial.”

7.verse: When he said this, an argument broke out between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided.

8.verse: (For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel nor spirit, but the Pharisees confess them all.)

9.verse: Then there arose a great uproar, and certain of the scribes of the party of the Pharisees stood up and protested vigorously, saying, “We find nothing evil in this man. What if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him?”

10.verse: And when the argument became violent, the commanding officer, afraid that Paul would be torn apart by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him away from among them by force and bring him into the barracks.

11.verse: The following night the Lord stood by him and said, “Take courage, for as you have testified to the facts about me in Jerusalem, so must you also testify in Rome.”

12.verse: When it was day, the Jews made a plot and bound themselves by an oath saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.

13.verse: There were more than forty who made this conspiracy.

14.verse: These went to the chief priests and elders and said, “We have bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food until we have killed Paul.

15.verse: So now you and the council give notice to the commanding officer to bring him down to you, as though you were going to examine his case more accurately; and we will be ready to kill him before he gets there.”

16.verse: But when the son of Paul’s sister heard about the ambush, he went and entered the barracks and reported it to Paul.

17.verse: Then Paul called one of the centurions and said, “Take this young man to the commanding officer, for he has something to report to him.”

18.verse: So he took him and brought him to the commanding officer and said, “The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this young man to you, as he has something to say to you.”

19.verse: The commanding officer took him by the hand, drew him aside and asked, “What is it that you have to report to me?”

20.verse: And he said, “The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul down tomorrow to the council, as though the case against him was going to be examined more closely.

21.verse: But you should not be persuaded by them, for more than forty of their men are lying in wait for him and have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink until they kill him. And now they are ready, awaiting your consent.”

22.verse: So the commanding officer dismissed the young man, charging him to tell no one that you have reported these things to me.”

23.verse: Then he called two of the centurions and said, “Get ready by the third hour of the night two hundred soldiers, seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen to go as far as Caesarea.”

24.verse: And he told them to provide mounts so that having put Paul on them they might bring him safely to Felix the governor.

25.verse: And he wrote a letter having this form:

26.verse: “Claudius Lysias, to the most excellent governor, Felix, greetings.

27.verse: This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them, when I came upon him and, with the soldiers, rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen.

28.verse: And wanting to know the charge for which they were accusing him, I brought him down to their council.

29.verse: I found him accused in regard to questions of their law, but with no charge deserving death or imprisonment.

30.verse: And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to speak against him to you.”

31.verse: So the soldiers, according to the directions given to them, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.

32.verse: The next day they let the horsemen go on with him, and they returned to the barracks.

33.verse: When the horsemen arrived in Caesarea, they delivered the letter to the governor and turned over Paul to him.

34.verse: When he had read the letter, he asked from what province he was. Learning that he was from Cilicia,

35.verse: he said, “I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive.” Then he commanded that Paul be guarded in Herod’s headquarters.

1.verse: And after five days the high priest Ananias went down with some elders and a prosecuting attorney, one Tertullus; and they laid before the governor their case against Paul.

2.verse: And when he was summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying: “Since we have enjoyed a long period of peace through your rule, and since reforms are being made in the nation by your foresight,

3.verse: in every way and everywhere we accept them, most excellent Felix, with all gratitude.

4.verse: But, that I may not detain you any longer, I beg you to hear us briefly in your kindness.

5.verse: For we found this man to be a troublemaker, one who stirs up riots among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the sect of the Nazarenes.

6.verse: He even tried to desecrate the temple, so we laid hold of him.

7.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

8.verse: When you examine him yourself, you will be able to learn from him about all these things of which we are accusing him.”

9.verse: And the Jews also joined the attack, saying that it was so.

10.verse: And Paul responded, when the governor motioned to him to speak: “Knowing that for many years you have been a judge over this nation, gladly do I make my own defense concerning these things.

11.verse: As you are able to verify for yourself, it is not more than twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem,

12.verse: and they did not find me arguing with anyone or stirring up a crowd, either in the temple or in the synagogues or in the city.

13.verse: Neither can they provide proof to you regarding the things of which they are now accusing me.

14.verse: But this I confess to you, that according to the Way, which they call a sect, thus I worship the God of our fathers, believing all things that are according to the Law and written in the Prophets,

15.verse: having a hope in God, which these men themselves accept, that there is to be a resurrection both of the just and of the unjust.

16.verse: In view of this I do my best to have a clear conscience toward God and men at all times.

17.verse: “Now, after several years, I came to my people bringing gifts for the poor and presenting offerings,

18.verse: which I was doing when they found me, ritually purified in the temple, without a crowd and without a commotion.

19.verse: But there are some Jews from Asia who ought to be here before you and bring charges, if they have anything against me.

20.verse: Or let these men themselves tell what wrongdoing they found when I stood before the council,

21.verse: other than this one utterance that I cried out while standing among them: ‘It is regarding a resurrection for the dead that I am on trial before you this day.’”

22.verse: But Felix, knowing more exactly the facts concerning the Way, put them off, saying, “When Lysias the commanding officer comes down, I will decide your case.”

23.verse: Then he commanded the centurion to keep him in custody, but to let him have some freedom and not to prevent any of his friends from taking care of his needs.

24.verse: After some days Felix arrived with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish. He sent for Paul and heard him speak about faith in Christ Jesus.

25.verse: And as he reasoned with him about righteousness and self-control and the judgment to come, Felix became frightened and said, “For the present go away, but when I find time I will send for you.”

26.verse: At the same time he hoped that money would be given to him by Paul. So he sent for him frequently and conversed with him.

27.verse: When two years had passed, Felix was replaced by Porcius Festus, and wanting to curry favor with the Jews, Felix left Paul in prison.

1.verse: Three days after arriving in the province, Festus went up to Jerusalem from Caesarea.

2.verse: So the chief priests and the Jewish leaders brought formal charges against Paul, begging him

3.verse: and asking him to do them a favor against Paul; they urged Festus to transfer him to Jerusalem, for they were forming a plot to kill him along the way.

4.verse: So then Festus replied that Paul was being kept at Caesarea but that he himself intended to go there shortly.

5.verse: “So,” he said, “let your leaders go down there with me, and if there is in this man anything improper, let them bring charges against him.”

6.verse: After he stayed among them not more than eight or ten days, he went down to Caesarea, and the next day he took his seat on the judge’s bench and ordered Paul to be brought.

7.verse: When he arrived, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing many and serious charges against him, which they were not able to prove.

8.verse: Paul argued in his defense, “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar have I committed any offense.”

9.verse: But Festus, wanting to curry favor with the Jews, responded to Paul, saying, “Do you want to go up to Jerusalem and there be tried on these charges before me?”

10.verse: Paul answered, “I am now standing before Caesar’s judgment seat, where I ought to be tried. Against the Jews I have done nothing wrong, as you yourself know very well.

11.verse: If then I am a wrongdoer and have done anything worthy of death, I am not trying to escape death; but if there is nothing to their charges against me, no one has a right to turn me over to them. I appeal to Caesar.”

12.verse: Then Festus, after conferring with the council, replied, “To Caesar you have appealed; to Caesar you will go.”

13.verse: Now after some days had passed, Agrippa the king and Bernice came down to Caesarea and paid their respects to Festus.

14.verse: Since they were staying there several days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king, saying, “There is a man left by Felix, a prisoner.

15.verse: When I came to Jerusalem, the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me about him, asking for a guilty verdict against him.

16.verse: I answered them that it was not the custom of the Romans to turn anyone over before the accused has met the accusers face to face and had an opportunity to make his defense against the charge.

17.verse: So when they met here, I made no delay, but on the next day took my seat on the judge’s bench and ordered the man to be brought.

18.verse: When the accusers stood up, they brought no charge against him of such evils as I was expecting,

19.verse: but had certain questions about their own religion to put to him and about a certain Jesus, who was dead, whom Paul claimed to be alive.

20.verse: Since I was uncertain about how to investigate such questions, I asked if he wanted to go to Jerusalem to be tried there on these charges.

21.verse: But when Paul had appealed to be kept in custody for the decision of the emperor, I ordered him to be held until I could send him to Caesar.”

22.verse: Then Agrippa said to Festus, “I too would like to hear the man myself.” “Tomorrow,” said he, “you will hear him.”

23.verse: So on the next day when Agrippa and Bernice came with great pomp and entered the audience hall along with the commanding officers and the prominent men of the city, and when Festus had given the order, Paul was brought in.

24.verse: And Festus said, “King Agrippa, and all men present with us, you see this man about whom the whole Jewish people petitioned me, both in Jerusalem and here, crying out that he ought not to live any longer.

25.verse: But I found that he had done nothing worthy of death; and since he himself appealed to the emperor, I decided to send him.

26.verse: But I do not have anything definite about him to write to my lord. Therefore I have brought him before you all, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that, when the examination has been conducted, I may have something to write.

27.verse: For it seems unreasonable to me, in sending a prisoner, not to also report the charges against him.”

1.verse: So Agrippa said to Paul, “You have permission to speak for yourself.” Then Paul stretched out his hand and began to make his defense:

2.verse: “Regarding all the things of which I am being accused by the Jews, King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that it is before you that I am about to make my defense today,

3.verse: especially because you are well acquainted with all the customs and controversies of the Jews. Therefore I beg you to listen to me patiently.

4.verse: All the Jews know my manner of life from my youth, which from the beginning was spent among my own people in Jerusalem,

5.verse: for they have known me from the first, if they are willing to go on record, that I lived as a Pharisee according to the strictest party of our religious system.

6.verse: And now I stand here on trial because of my hope in the promise made by God to our fathers,

7.verse: to which our twelve tribes hope to attain, worshipping strenuously night and day. It is for this hope, your Excellency, that I am being accused by Jews!

8.verse: Why is it thought incredible among you that God raises the dead?

9.verse: I thought to myself that I ought to do many deeds hostile to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

10.verse: And I did so in Jerusalem; not only did I lock up in prison many of the saints, after receiving authority from the chief priests, but also when they were put to death I cast my vote against them.

11.verse: And I punished them often in all the synagogues and tried to make them blaspheme; and since I was so vehemently angry at them, I pursued them even to foreign cities.

12.verse: “On one of these journeys I was going to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,

13.verse: and at midday I saw on the way, O king, a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, that shone around me and those who journeyed with me.

14.verse: And when we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in the Hebrew language, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.’

15.verse: And I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.

16.verse: But get up and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you a servant and witness both to the things in which you have seen me and to those in which I will appear to you.

17.verse: I will rescue you from your people and from the Gentiles, to whom I am sending you

18.verse: to open their eyes, that they may turn from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a place among those who are sanctified by faith in me.’

19.verse: So then, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,

20.verse: but I declared to those in Damascus first, then also to those in Jerusalem and through all the region of Judea, and to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, performing works worthy of repentance.

21.verse: It was for that reason that the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.

22.verse: Obtaining help, therefore, from God, until this day I have stood testifying both to small and great, saying nothing beyond what the prophets and Moses said would come to pass:

23.verse: that the Christ was to suffer and, as the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles.”

24.verse: As Paul was saying these things in his defense, Festus said in a loud voice, “You are out of your mind, Paul! Much learning is driving you insane!”

25.verse: But Paul said, “I am not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but true and rational are the words that I declare.

26.verse: For the king knows about these matters, and to him I am speaking boldly, for I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice, for this was not done in a corner.

27.verse: Do you believe, King Agrippa, in the prophets? I know that you believe.”

28.verse: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “In too short a time you believe you are making a Christian of me.”

29.verse: Paul replied, “I would to God that whether the time be short or long, not only you but also all those who are listening to me today would also become as I am, except for these chains.”

30.verse: Then the king stood up, and the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them;

31.verse: and after they had left the room, they spoke to one another, saying, “This man is doing nothing worthy of death or imprisonment.”

32.verse: And Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.”

1.verse: And when it was decided that we would sail for Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion, named Julius, of the Augustan Cohort.

2.verse: And embarking on a ship from Adramyttium, which was about to sail to ports along the coast of Asia, we put to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica was with us.

3.verse: The next day we put in at Sidon; and Julius treated Paul kindly and allowed him to go to his friends and be cared for.

4.verse: And putting out to sea from there, we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were against us.

5.verse: And when we had sailed across the open sea along the coast of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra in Lycia.

6.verse: There the centurion found a ship from Alexandria sailing for Italy and put us on board it.

7.verse: We sailed slowly for a number of days and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, and as the wind did not allow us to go farther, we sailed under the lee of Crete off Salmone.

8.verse: Sailing past it with difficulty, we came to a place called Fair Havens, near to which was the city Lasea.

9.verse: Since considerable time had passed and the voyage was now dangerous because the fast had already gone by, Paul advised them,

10.verse: saying, “Gentlemen, I perceive that the voyage that is about to take place will involve injury and much loss, not only of the cargo and the ship, but also of our lives.”

11.verse: But the centurion was more convinced by the captain and the ship’s owner than by what Paul was saying.

12.verse: And since the harbor was unsuitable to winter in, the majority made a decision to put out to sea from there, if somehow they might be able to reach Phoenix, a harbor of Crete, facing both southwest and northwest, and spend the winter there.

13.verse: Now when the south wind blew gently, thinking that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete, close to the shore.

14.verse: But soon a violent wind, called the northeaster, rushed down from Crete.

15.verse: And when the ship was caught by it and could not head into the wind, we gave way and allowed ourselves to be driven along.

16.verse: Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we were able with difficulty to get the dinghy under control.

17.verse: After hoisting it up, they passed cables under the ship to hold it together. Then, fearing that they would run aground on the Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor, and thus they let the ship be driven along.

18.verse: Since we were being pounded so violently by the storm, the next day they began to throw cargo overboard;

19.verse: and on the third day they threw the ship’s tackle overboard with their own hands.

20.verse: When neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small storm continued to rage, all hope of our being saved was at last abandoned.

21.verse: Since they had long been without food, Paul stood up in their midst and said, “Men, you should have followed my advice and not set sail from Crete and incurred this injury and loss.

22.verse: And now I advise you to be of good courage; for there will be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.

23.verse: For there stood by me this night an angel of the God whose I am and whom I serve,

24.verse: saying, ‘Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar; and behold, God has granted you as a gift all those who sail with you.’

25.verse: So be of good courage, men, for I have faith in God that it will be so, just as it has been told me.

26.verse: But we must run aground on some island.”

27.verse: And when it was the fourteenth night, as we were being driven about in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors suspected that they were nearing land.

28.verse: So they took soundings and found twenty fathoms; and after a short distance they took soundings again and found fifteen fathoms.

29.verse: Fearing that we might run aground on the rocky coast, they dropped four anchors from the stern and prayed for day to come.

30.verse: But when the sailors tried to escape from the ship and had lowered the dinghy into the sea pretending they intended to let down anchors from the bow,

31.verse: Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, “If these men do not remain in the ship, you cannot be saved.”

32.verse: Then the soldiers cut the ropes from the dinghy and let it drift away.

33.verse: As day was about to dawn, Paul urged them all to take some food, saying, “Today is the fourteenth day that you have continued in suspense and been without food, having taken nothing.

34.verse: Therefore I urge you to take some food; for this is for your survival, for not a hair will perish from the head of any of you.”

35.verse: And when he had said these things, he took bread, and giving thanks to God before them all, he broke it and began to eat.

36.verse: So everyone was encouraged and they themselves took food.

37.verse: We were in all two hundred seventy-six persons on the ship.

38.verse: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, throwing the wheat out into the sea.

39.verse: Now when it was day, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a bay that had a beach, on which they planned, if possible, to run the ship ashore.

40.verse: So they cut loose the anchors, left them in the sea, and at the same time untied the ropes that held the rudders. Then hoisting the foresail to the wind, they made for the beach.

41.verse: But caught in some crosscurrents, they ran the ship aground; the bow stuck and remained immovable, but the stern began to break up by the force of the waves.

42.verse: It was the plan of the soldiers to kill the prisoners, so none could escape by swimming away.

43.verse: But the centurion, wanting to spare Paul’s life, prevented them from carrying out their plan; and he ordered those who could swim to throw themselves overboard first and make for the land,

44.verse: and the rest, some on planks and others on pieces of the ship. And so it came about that all escaped safely to the land.

1.verse: And when we had escaped safely, then we learned that the island was called Malta.

2.verse: The native people showed us no ordinary kindness, for they kindled a fire and welcomed us all, because it had begun to rain and because of the cold.

3.verse: When Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and put them on the fire, a viper came out from the heat and fastened onto his hand.

4.verse: When the native people saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to each other, “Certainly this man is a murderer, and though he has escaped from the sea, justice has not allowed him to live.”

5.verse: But Paul shook the creature off into the fire and suffered no harm.

6.verse: They were expecting that he was going to swell up or suddenly fall down dead; but when they waited a long time and saw no misfortune happen to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.

7.verse: Now in the region around that place were fields belonging to the leading man of the island, by name Publius, who welcomed us and for three days entertained us hospitably.

8.verse: It happened that the father of Publius lay sick with bouts of fever and with dysentery. Paul visited him, and when he had prayed, he laid his hands on him and healed him.

9.verse: And when this happened, the rest of the people on the island who had diseases also came and were cured.

10.verse: They also honored us with many honors, and when we were getting ready to sail, they put on board whatever we needed.

11.verse: After three months we put out to sea in a ship that had wintered at the island, a ship of Alexandria, with the “Heavenly Twins” as a figurehead.

12.verse: And when we put in at Syracuse, we stayed there three days.

13.verse: From there we circled round and came to Rhegium; and after one day a south wind came up, and on the following day we arrived in Puteoli,

14.verse: where we found brethren, and were invited to stay with them seven days. And so we went toward Rome.

15.verse: And the brothers there, when they heard about us, came as far as the Forum of Appius and Three Taverns to meet us. On seeing them, Paul gave thanks to God and took courage.

16.verse: And when we entered Rome, Paul was allowed to stay by himself, with a soldier guarding him.

17.verse: And it happened that after three days Paul called together the leaders of the Jews. And when they gathered, he said to them: “My brothers, though I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.

18.verse: They examined me and wanted to release me, because there was no basis for a death sentence against me.

19.verse: But when the Jews objected, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, but not as though I had some charge to bring against my own people.

20.verse: For this reason, therefore, I have asked to see you and speak with you, since it is because of the hope of Israel that I wear this chain.”

21.verse: And they said to him, “We have received no letters from Judea about you, nor have any of the brothers come from there and reported or spoken any bad about you.

22.verse: But we desire to hear from you what you think, for with regard to this sect it is known to us that everywhere it is spoken against.”

23.verse: When they had arranged a day to meet with him, many came to him at his lodging, and he expounded to them, testifying to the kingdom of God and trying to convince them about Jesus both from the Law of Moses and from the Prophets, from morning till evening.

24.verse: And some were convinced by what he said, but others refused to believe.

25.verse: And not being in harmony among themselves, they departed after Paul made one further statement. “The Holy Spirit was right in saying to your fathers through Isaiah the prophet:

26.verse: “‘Go to this people, and say, “You will indeed hear but never understand, and you will indeed see but never perceive”;

27.verse: for the heart of this people has become dull, and they hear with difficultly with their ears, and their eyes they have closed, lest they should see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their heart and turn, and I should heal them.’

28.verse: So let it be known to you that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles; even they will listen.”

29.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

30.verse: Paul lived there two whole years in his own rented house and welcomed all who came to him,

31.verse: proclaiming the kingdom of God and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness, without hindrance.
